dataset.title: Phenology of selected cavity-nesting Hymenoptera and flowering plant taxa in the Colorado Rocky Mountains from 2008 to 2010

creator.organizationName: Department of Entomology, University of California, Davis

abstract.para: Data come from fourteen sites in the West Elk Mountains of Colorado, USA. The study aimed to identify the factors regulating phenology of plants and cavity-nesting insects, and to determine the likelihood of asynchrony between flowering and pollinator emergence under climate change. Numbers of flowers or flowering stems of several abundant species were counted 2-3 times weekly along variable-width belt transects in May-July 2008 and 2009. Insect data are from experimental nest blocks colonized naturally by cavity-nesting insects in 2007 and 2008. Emergence traps on these nest blocks were monitored 2-3 times weekly in 2008 (for 2007 nests) and 2009-2010 (2008 nests) to characterize insect phenology. All Hymenoptera, excluding Ichneumonoidea, were identified to species, if possible. A reciprocal transplant experiment was conducted using nest blocks at two of the sites in 2007-2008, and a study of nest-height effects on emergence phenology was conducted at one site in 2008-2010. For each individual nest or nest block on each sampling date, we recorded the number of individuals, their sex, the number already dead at the time of capture, and the experimental treatment (when appropriate). Dataloggers recorded temperature and light hourly at each study site; these data are deposited separately with Ecological Archives.

additionalInfo.para: Available as one Excel file (.xls or .xlsx) or as two separate tab-delimited text files (.txt).

intellectualRights.para: Obtain permission from data set owner(s)

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Subalpine meadow sites around the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory and the town of Crested Butte in Gunnison County, Colorado, USA.

contact.organizationName: Department of Entomology, University of California, Davis

section.title: Plant and insect phenology monitoring
section.para: Consult Forrest & Thomson 2011 (Ecological Monographs) for details.

description.para:
With few exceptions, sites used in 2008 were visited every 2-3 days from 12 May to 21 July for both plant and insect sampling. Insects were sampled approximately once per week thereafter, until 20 August 2008. Sites used in 2009-2010 were visited every 3-4 days from 1 May to 31 July 2009 for plant and insect sampling, and then approximately weekly until 19 September 2009 for insects only. Nest blocks set out and colonized in 2008 were also monitored approximately weekly from 29 May to 13 July 2010 for emergence of insects with two-year life cycles.
All insects caught in emergence traps were collected or identified in the field and released. Cavity-nesting bees and wasps, excluding Ichneumonoidea, were identified to species. Identifications were confirmed by experts on Megachilidae (Terry Griswold, USDA-ARS, Logan, UT, USA) and Eumeninae (Matthias Buck, Royal Alberta Museum, Edmonton, AB, Canada).
Not all plants in flower at a site were recorded. We focused only on abundant, widespread, and easily counted taxa that are primarily animal-pollinated. After early July 2009, data were recorded for only seven flowering taxa: Mertensia fusiformis (or M. brevistyla), Delphinium nuttallianum, Viola praemorsa, Lathyrus leucanthus, Helianthella quinquenervis, Linum lewisii, and Potentilla gracilis x hippiana. On rare occasions early in the season, sites were visited but plant transects were not conducted. If a plant was observed flowering but was not counted, abundance was recorded simply as â€œ>0â€.

samplingDescription.para: Consult Forrest & Thomson 2011 (Ecological Monographs) for details.
